titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Amy L. Lettick Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Carol King

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 10:52

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, journals and diaries, audio and video tapes, films, and publications relating to the development and care of an autistic child and the founding of the Benhaven school.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright is retained by the creator(s) of this collection for materials they have authored or otherwise produced. After the lifetime of the creator(s), copyright passes to Yale University. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Amy L. Lettick Papers (MS 1593). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Amy L. Lettick, 1990-1992, and 1998, 1999.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Amy L. Lettick was the founder of Benhaven, a private, nonprofit school community in New Haven for autistic and neurologically impaired individuals. Benhaven was founded in 1967 as an outgrowth of Lettick's search for an educational and social program for her autistic son, Benjamin. In 1975, Yale University conferred an honorary doctorate upon Amy Lettick for her work with autistic children and the founding of Benhaven. Lettick died on November 22, 2017 in Tempe, Arizona.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, journals and diaries, audio and video tapes, films, and publications relating to the development and care of an autistic child and the founding of the Benhaven school.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy of non-commercially produced items for their personal use should consult the ordering reproductions information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

Original born digital files, as well as preservation masters, may not be accessed due to their fragility. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist request that they be made. Born digital files cannot be accessed remotely. System requirements include a Manuscripts and Archives computer and file viewing software.

scopecontent.p: Preliminary inventory by Carol King, 1991 May

Incomplete original foreword of journal by Sylvia Kottler
Correspondence, notes and newspaper clipping found in 1937 dairy
Photographs of Benjamin Lettick and his family
Presentation on learning behavior of the child, by Dr. Newell Kephart at the state convention of the Texas Society for Crippled Children and Adults
"The Brain Injured Child, and the Slow Learner in the Classroom," class lecture by Newell Kephart, Purdue University
Lecture notes and related material on the care of autistic children

Benhaven at Work, Vol. II: January-June 1984 (part 2), by Amy L. Lettick

Correspondence and printed material pertaining to Benhaven Press publications and others

Program #1 - Applied Academics: Developing a Functional Curriculum Using Applied Academics and Practical Living Skills

Program #7 - Vocational and Work Activity Benchwork, Horticultural and Farm Activities
Program #8 - Teaching Autistic People How to Play
Program #11 - Administration of Benhaven's Residential Program
Program #12 - A Model for Operating a School/ Vocational Training Program for Autistic Children and Adolescents
Tape #11 - Goal Setting: Its Form and Function (Parts 1 and 2)
Tape #12 - Addressing and Teaching the Autistic (Parts 1 and 2)
Update of Yale Benhaven film, interview at end (Part 2)
Matt Hochman Keyboard and Dancing; Jarrod Law Doing the Twist
